awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Tele-rehabilitation system for individuals with upper limb motor dysfunction
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project focuses on the development of a low-cost tele-rehabilitation system for individuals with motor dysfunction. Numerous technology-enabled tele-rehabilitation systems presently exist, but their relatively high cost, safety concerns, and bulkiness often limit their application in decentralized environments. This project involves the development of a low-cost, sensor-enabled mobile health system that records body movements and derives quantitative metrics that are meaningful to both clinicians and patients. Commercialization of this technology has the potential to improve the way that sensorimotor disorders are managed in individuals with neurological and musculoskeletal impairments.  The technology platform could serve as a model for home-based tele-rehabilitation, improving clinical practice and access to care.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a low-cost, sensor-enabled system for upper limb rehabilitation that combines mobile technology, micro-electromechanical system inertial measurement units, sensor-fusion algorithms, and biomechanics. The system provides a way for rehabilitation clinicians to accurately quantify movement quality and monitor patient compliance and quality of life. The technology will be applied to assess motor dysfunction in stroke survivors and patients with acquired traumatic brain injury. Test accuracy, consistency, reliability and validity of the system's measurements will be demonstrated.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Throughout the seven-week NSF-ICORPS program, we explored the potential for commercialization of a sensor-enabled tele-health system that allows individuals to continue their physical rehabilitation system in their home environment by interviewing a diverse group of 103 individuals including clinic owners, physical rehabilitation practitioners, physical fitness practitioners, health insurers, individuals with prior/current injuries, and individuals from other health technology companies.

At the beginning my team and I explored whether the physical rehabilitation or personal fitness market would be the best fit for our product. Our customer discovery interviews revealed that the personal fitness market is already saturated with mobile applications, with interviewees stating that a wearable sensor was not a valuable value proposition for their business model. Moreover, because of the out-of-pocket pricing structure personal fitness professionals felt that the cost of our system would negatively impact their profit margin. Congruent with our hypothesis, physical rehabilitation professionals stated that a sensor-enabled tele-health system would increase patient compliance, improve patient outcomes, and expand their geographical reach. Interestingly, and contrary to our initial hypothesis that clinic owners would care about compliance, it turns out that clinic owners are more concerned with upfront costs and short-term revenue and would only adopt health technologies if they were reimbursable. Taken together, our results indicated that our sensor-enabled technology has a better product-market fit with the physical therapy market. Thus, we decided to focus resources on the physical rehabilitation market as the initial beachhead market and eliminate the physical fitness market from further consideration.

A common theme throughout the interviews with clinic owners, physical rehabilitation practitioners, and health insurers was the impact of health insurance and medical reimbursement for physical therapy services. This field relies heavily on insurance and reimbursement, and as such, our product would need to go through the FDA 510(k) premarket notification process to demonstrate that the device to be marketed is as safe and effective, and then obtain the appropriate Healthcare Common Procedure Coding System (HCPCS) Codes to attain reimbursement for our product. These considerations will have substantial impact on commercialization pathway and fundraising activities, but are necessary to enter the market.

We postulated that a volume dependent pricing model would be most responsive to different clinic sizes and tested this hypothesis by interviewing individuals with current or prior injuries that required physical rehabilitation, as well as physical rehabilitation professionals and clinic owners. Overall, clinic owners and physical rehabilitation professionals could not articulate how much they would pay for the wearable sensor and mobile app subscription due to a lack of knowledge of the general tele-health pricing structure. However, when we offered our own estimates, owners said that they were reasonable if the short-term return on investment (ROI) allowed them to recoup the cost of the system. According to our interviews with prior/current injured people, their willingness to purchase the sensor (versus leasing from a clinic) would be increased if it could be used by other family members, and for any potential future injuries.

The broader impact of our technology is helping physical rehabilitation clinics and hospital systems to provide accessible and cost-effective health services that ameliorate the barriers that survivors and their caretakers face while further reducing the on strain placed on profession healthcare providers. We found that this is a current need and, therefore, we believe there might be also an actual market for our technology that can enable patients to receive care in their homes.

 


Last Modified: 06/02/2023
Modified by: Charmayne M Hughes
por.por_txt_cntn:
Throughout the seven-week NSF-ICORPS program, we explored the potential for commercialization of a sensor-enabled tele-health system that allows individuals to continue their physical rehabilitation system in their home environment by interviewing a diverse group of 103 individuals including clinic owners, physical rehabilitation practitioners, physical fitness practitioners, health insurers, individuals with prior/current injuries, and individuals from other health technology companies.

At the beginning my team and I explored whether the physical rehabilitation or personal fitness market would be the best fit for our product. Our customer discovery interviews revealed that the personal fitness market is already saturated with mobile applications, with interviewees stating that a wearable sensor was not a valuable value proposition for their business model. Moreover, because of the out-of-pocket pricing structure personal fitness professionals felt that the cost of our system would negatively impact their profit margin. Congruent with our hypothesis, physical rehabilitation professionals stated that a sensor-enabled tele-health system would increase patient compliance, improve patient outcomes, and expand their geographical reach. Interestingly, and contrary to our initial hypothesis that clinic owners would care about compliance, it turns out that clinic owners are more concerned with upfront costs and short-term revenue and would only adopt health technologies if they were reimbursable. Taken together, our results indicated that our sensor-enabled technology has a better product-market fit with the physical therapy market. Thus, we decided to focus resources on the physical rehabilitation market as the initial beachhead market and eliminate the physical fitness market from further consideration.

A common theme throughout the interviews with clinic owners, physical rehabilitation practitioners, and health insurers was the impact of health insurance and medical reimbursement for physical therapy services. This field relies heavily on insurance and reimbursement, and as such, our product would need to go through the FDA 510(k) premarket notification process to demonstrate that the device to be marketed is as safe and effective, and then obtain the appropriate Healthcare Common Procedure Coding System (HCPCS) Codes to attain reimbursement for our product. These considerations will have substantial impact on commercialization pathway and fundraising activities, but are necessary to enter the market.

We postulated that a volume dependent pricing model would be most responsive to different clinic sizes and tested this hypothesis by interviewing individuals with current or prior injuries that required physical rehabilitation, as well as physical rehabilitation professionals and clinic owners. Overall, clinic owners and physical rehabilitation professionals could not articulate how much they would pay for the wearable sensor and mobile app subscription due to a lack of knowledge of the general tele-health pricing structure. However, when we offered our own estimates, owners said that they were reasonable if the short-term return on investment (ROI) allowed them to recoup the cost of the system. The broader impact of our technology is helping physical rehabilitation clinics and hospital systems to provide accessible and cost-effective health services that ameliorate the barriers that survivors and their caretakers face while further reducing the on strain placed on profession healthcare providers.
